ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We worked on our thesis papers over the course of the year. I learned a bit about the topics of my peers and had the experience of writing a 60 page thesis. Obviously I learned plenty about my own topic!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Zadeh gave us a lot of feedback throughout the term, which I appreciated a lot. He did not assign busy work. If we were ahead of the bench marker, he would not make us go back and do work that would not be helpful just to check a box; I really appreciated that! I also appreciated that our thesis was due long before the end of the semester, meaning I had a two-week break before the end of term and exam week. That was solid timing too. He was also understanding if there was a course-overlap, which gave additional flexibility and enabled me to take a course that was important for me pre-professionally while still staying well on track for his course and the writing of the thesis.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In a virtual format it was significantly more difficult to access library resources. They just took more time to mail and mail back than it would take to walk to a library and check out a book. Research just took longer than it does during a normal semester. I think it was also more difficult to connect with the rest of Yale, especially Professors who were not great at using zoom or regularly keeping up with their emails. People whose office hours you could normally just walk into were much more difficult to reach.

I have already given my feedback to the Professor in class, but for the purpose of evaluation, I will say that this class was well-organized and it was a productive experience towards writing the thesis. I am grateful for Professor Zadeh's support.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are a RLST student, it's required but it's well worth it. If you are not an RLST major, but want to write an additional thesis paper, then this course is for you!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
